elements.title: Replace the Human Signifier with a Coherent System Image
elements.problem: The platform has no independent system image. Susan's entire interaction with Split Lease is mediated by Bryant — a human being who serves as the sole signifier for the service's identity, operational model, and trustworthiness. Susan misidentifies Split Lease as a real estate brokerage (4:55: 'Real estate Agent'), requiring Bryant to verbally correct her conceptual model. She never encounters the platform's interface, search page, or listing page. Norman's system image principle states that 'the designer of the product and the person using the product form somewhat disconnected vertices of a triangle' and 'the entire burden of communication is on the system image.' Split Lease's system image does not exist independently of Bryant. If Bryant is removed from the interaction, the user has no triangle vertex to form a conceptual model from — the system image collapses entirely.
elements.solution: Build a system image that can communicate Split Lease's identity, purpose, and operational model without human mediation. This requires: (1) The landing page must signify what Split Lease IS within 5 seconds — not 'a marketplace' (too generic) but 'part-time housing: book the nights you need, not the ones you don't.' The signifier must be perceivable to someone whose existing conceptual model of housing is 'full-time occupancy.' (2) Every page must carry the core signifier: this is not a hotel, not Airbnb, not a real estate brokerage — it is schedule-native shared housing. The system image must be consistent across all touchpoints so the guest can form one coherent conceptual model. (3) The first interaction should not require Bryant. A guest who arrives at the site via a link, a search result, or a referral must be able to understand what actions are possible (Norman's discoverability) without calling anyone. (4) When a human intermediary IS involved, the platform should bridge from the human to the digital: Bryant's name, the listing discussed, and the terms mentioned should appear on the platform so it feels like a continuation of the conversation, not a disconnected system.

evidence.quote: Real estate Agent.
evidence.insight: Susan's misidentification reveals that the platform communicates nothing about itself. Her conceptual model defaults to the closest familiar category (real estate brokerage) because Split Lease's actual category has no signifier she can perceive.

evidence.quote: When the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, then the user cannot easily use the device. If it is incomplete or contradictory, there will be trouble.
evidence.insight: Split Lease's system image is not merely incoherent — it is absent. The user's only available system image is Bryant's verbal explanation, which is ephemeral and cannot be revisited.

evidence.quote: I'm looking for a guest who would need this space basically for any non-continuous set of nights... Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan defaults to 'seven nights a week' because her conceptual model of housing does not include non-continuous occupancy. The platform's core value proposition has no signifier that would correct this model without human intervention.

evidence.quote: Two of the most important characteristics of good design are discoverability and understanding. Discoverability: Is it possible to even figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them?
evidence.insight: Susan cannot discover what Split Lease does, let alone what actions it affords. Discoverability requires affordances, signifiers, constraints, mappings, and feedback working together — none of which Susan encounters from the platform itself.

elements.user_goal: Understand within seconds what this service is, what it offers, and whether it can solve my specific problem — without needing to talk to a human first.
elements.company_goal: Enable platform-mediated discovery and conversion so that growth is not bottlenecked by the number of human intermediaries available to explain the service.
elements.time_budget: Under 10 seconds to form a correct conceptual model of what Split Lease is. Under 30 seconds to understand whether any listings match the guest's needs.
anti_goals: DO NOT rely on marketing language that describes the company rather than signifying what the user can do. 'We connect hosts and guests' is not a signifier. 'Book 3 nights a week in a private room near Lincoln Tunnel' is.
DO NOT use internal jargon ('non-continuous set of nights', 'lease style', 'periodic tenancy') as user-facing signifiers. These terms require human translation.
DO NOT hide the human fallback. Some guests will always need to talk to someone. The platform should make this accessible, not eliminate it.
elements.success_metric: First-visit comprehension rate: percentage of new visitors who can correctly describe what Split Lease does after 30 seconds on the landing page (testable via 5-second usability tests). Target: above 70%.

elements.title: Surface Trust Signifiers That Replace Physical Inspection
elements.problem: Susan demands to physically inspect the space three times in the call (2:14, 3:05, 3:42). She is told that pre-booking inspection is not allowed for privacy reasons. This creates an anti-affordance — a deliberate prevention of interaction — but the anti-affordance has no discoverable signifier explaining WHY it exists or WHAT substitutes are available. Norman states that anti-affordances must be discoverable and perceivable, or the user will walk into the glass wall. Susan's prior experience with housing scams ('you know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around,' 2:22) means her default conceptual model for remote housing is 'likely fraud.' The listing page's current signifiers — whatever they may be — are insufficient to overcome this default model. Susan explicitly proposes photos as a substitute signifier (3:42), and Bryant improvises a first-night cancellation guarantee (3:16), but neither of these critical affordances is discoverable through the platform itself.
elements.solution: Build a layered trust signifier system that makes the anti-affordance (no pre-booking inspection) acceptable by making its substitutes prominently discoverable. This requires: (1) Verified photos as primary trust signifiers — not optional, not thumbnail-sized, but prominent, labeled as verified, and comprehensive (room, bathroom, common areas, building entrance). Susan specifically asked about the room and bathroom (1:08); the photos must cover exactly what guests ask about. (2) First-night cancellation guarantee as a prominently displayed signifier on the listing page and the acceptance screen. Bryant invented this on the fly (3:16); it must be a permanent, discoverable platform affordance. (3) Host identity verification signifiers — verified name, photo, response rate, reviews from prior guests. These replace the face-to-face meeting that Susan's friend cannot have because she is in Oregon. (4) An explicit signifier explaining the no-preview policy: 'For the host's privacy, we don't offer pre-booking tours. Instead, here's how we verify every listing...' Norman's principle: when you cannot make the anti-affordance invisible (like good glass), you must provide a signifier that explains it and directs the user to the substitute affordance.

evidence.quote: I do have to see the room before she puts her tickets. I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's demand for physical inspection is a trust requirement, not a preference. Her past scam experiences have created a conceptual model where remote housing = fraud until proven otherwise. The platform must provide signifiers that directly address this mental model.

evidence.quote: To be effective, affordances and anti-affordances have to be discoverable — perceivable. This poses a difficulty with glass... If an affordance or anti-affordance cannot be perceived, some means of signaling its presence is required: I call this property a signifier.
evidence.insight: The no-preview policy is a glass wall. Susan runs into it repeatedly. The platform needs a signifier that makes this anti-affordance perceivable AND directs the guest toward the substitute affordances (photos, reviews, cancellation guarantee).

evidence.quote: There would be something set up where if you come the first night and it's not something that would work, you have the flexibility to cancel.
evidence.insight: Bryant improvises the single most important trust affordance in the entire call — first-night cancellation. This affordance exists only in Bryant's verbal promise, not as a discoverable platform feature. Norman: 'Affordances exist even if they are not visible. For designers, their visibility is critical.'

evidence.quote: If I like the room in the bathroom, I can, should have pictures. And she said, it's okay. I'll give you the deposit right there.
evidence.insight: Susan spontaneously identifies photos as the acceptable substitute signifier for physical inspection, and immediately couples it with readiness to pay. The conversion path is: verified photos → trust → deposit. Missing photos = missing the entire conversion mechanism.

elements.user_goal: Know that the space is real, safe, and as described before committing money or booking travel — without needing to visit in person.
elements.company_goal: Convert trust-anxious guests by providing discoverable verification signifiers that eliminate the need for human-mediated trust building at the listing evaluation stage.
elements.time_budget: Trust signifiers must be visible within the first scroll of the listing page. The guest should not need to click into a separate section to find verification status, cancellation terms, or host identity.
anti_goals: DO NOT bury trust signifiers below the fold or behind expandable sections. If the guest must search for trust evidence, the signifier has failed.
DO NOT treat photos as optional or host-controlled quality. If photos are the primary substitute for physical inspection, they must be verified, comprehensive, and recent.
DO NOT present the cancellation guarantee only in legal fine print. It is the most important trust affordance and must be signified with the same visual prominence as the price.

DO NOT assume that trust is built once. Susan asked about legitimacy at three different points in the call — trust signifiers must be reinforced at listing evaluation, negotiation, acceptance, AND move-in.
elements.success_metric: Listing-to-proposal conversion rate for first-time guests who have not spoken to an agent. Target: above 15% (vs. current agent-mediated conversion). Secondary: percentage of listings with verified photos above 90%.

elements.title: Map Platform Controls to the Guest's Natural Language, Not Platform Terminology
elements.problem: Susan thinks in calendar months ('one month or two months,' 0:11), weekday names ('Monday to Friday,' implied by 'five nights a week'), and space types ('full apartment or bedroom,' 0:43). The platform thinks in night counts ('30 night minimum,' 1:35), lease styles, and feature taxonomies. Bryant must perform the mapping between these two vocabularies in real time — twice for the non-continuous nights concept (0:19-0:35 and 1:35-2:00) and once for the minimum stay requirement. Norman's mapping principle states that 'natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding.' The platform's input controls must map to the guest's natural way of thinking about their stay, not require the guest to translate their needs into platform-native units. When the mapping is unnatural, the guest cannot operate the controls correctly — or at all.
elements.solution: Design every input control to accept the guest's natural vocabulary and translate internally. This requires: (1) Duration selection: let guests select 'about 1 month' or 'about 2 months' and show the equivalent night count as secondary information ('approximately 30 nights'). Do not present a number field labeled 'nights.' (2) Schedule selection: provide one-click presets for common patterns — 'Weekdays (Mon-Fri),' 'Weekends (Sat-Sun),' 'Full week' — rather than requiring individual day toggles. Susan's friend needs 'Monday to Friday,' which should be a single tap. (3) Space type: use labels guests naturally use ('Private room with private bath,' 'Shared room,' 'Full apartment') rather than feature taxonomies. Susan asked 'is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom?' — those are the categories. (4) Location: show a map with neighborhood labels and transit proximity, not just a street address. Susan immediately oriented around the Lincoln Tunnel (5:35); the listing should signify proximity to landmarks the guest knows. (5) Every control should provide immediate visual feedback showing the mapping: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights, starting March 3.' This is the real-time translation Bryant performed verbally at 1:35-2:00.

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan's default conceptual model for housing is full-time occupancy. The non-continuous nights concept requires a signifier that communicates the model without jargon. 'Non-continuous set of nights' is platform language; 'pick the nights you need' is guest language.

evidence.quote: Natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding. For example, to move an object up, move the control up.
evidence.insight: A calendar-based duration selector where the guest taps weeks on a visual calendar is a natural mapping. A number field labeled 'minimum nights' is an arbitrary mapping that requires cognitive translation.

evidence.quote: Rita would require a 30 night minimum... five nights a week for like two months would be something that would, could work.
evidence.insight: Bryant performs the mapping between Susan's '1-2 months' and the platform's '30 night minimum' in real time. The proposal creation UI must perform this same mapping visually — showing the guest both their natural-language description and the platform's internal calculation simultaneously.

evidence.quote: When the model presented to us is inadequate or wrong (or, worse, nonexistent), we can have difficulties.
evidence.insight: Norman's refrigerator example shows that controls labeled in the system's vocabulary (freezer dial vs. temperature dial) create false conceptual models. Labels must use the user's vocabulary to create correct mental models of what the controls do.

elements.user_goal: Express my housing needs using words I already know — months, weekdays, private room — and have the platform understand me without requiring me to learn its terminology.
elements.company_goal: Eliminate the vocabulary translation barrier that prevents self-service booking, reducing dependency on human intermediaries to interpret guest needs.
elements.time_budget: Configuring a stay proposal (dates, schedule, duration) should take under 60 seconds using preset-based natural mappings. If the guest must think about how to express their need in platform terms, the mapping has failed.
anti_goals: DO NOT present minimum night counts as the primary framing for duration. Guests think in weeks and months, not night totals.
DO NOT require toggling individual days when a preset ('Weekdays') captures the intent in one tap.
DO NOT use dropdown menus with platform taxonomy categories. Use the guest's own vocabulary as labels.
DO NOT hide the platform's internal calculation. Show both: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months' AND '40 nights at $X/night = $Y total.' Transparency builds the correct conceptual model.
elements.success_metric: Proposal creation completion rate for unassisted guests (no agent involvement). Target: above 50%. Secondary: average time from search to submitted proposal under 5 minutes.

elements.title: Provide Immediate, Informative Feedback at Every Negotiation Action
elements.problem: The Susan call contains a real-time negotiation: Susan demands inspection, Bryant explains the policy, Susan pushes back, Bryant offers a compromise (first-night cancellation). At every exchange, both parties receive immediate verbal feedback — acknowledgment, explanation, counter-proposal. The platform's negotiation flow must replicate this feedback density, but digital interactions are prone to feedback gaps: submitted proposals that show 'pending' for days, counter-offers that arrive with no notification, status changes that are invisible unless the guest happens to check. Norman states that 'feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting.' The call itself demonstrates this: when the phone connection drops at 2:42-3:05, both parties scramble with 'Can you hear me?' — trust erodes within seconds of lost feedback. Every minute a guest waits for a response to a proposal, a date change request, or a negotiation counter is a minute their trust decays.
elements.solution: Design the negotiation and active lease flows with Norman's feedback hierarchy: immediate acknowledgment, informative status, and prioritized notifications. This requires: (1) Every guest action (submit proposal, request date change, send message, accept terms) must produce immediate visual feedback confirming the action was registered — not a spinner, but a contextual confirmation ('Your proposal has been sent to Rita. She typically responds within 4 hours.'). (2) Status updates must be pushed, not polled. The guest should never have to check whether something happened. Notifications must arrive via the guest's preferred channel (push notification, email, SMS) within minutes. (3) Feedback must be informative, not just confirmatory. 'Your date change was approved' is better than a green checkmark. 'Rita approved your date change. Your next stay is Monday March 10' is better still. (4) When delays are unavoidable (host has not responded), the platform must provide intermediate feedback: 'Rita has not yet responded. Most hosts respond within 6 hours. We will notify you immediately.' This is the digital equivalent of Bryant saying 'I'll keep you updated' (6:57). (5) Prioritize feedback: routine confirmations (stay confirmed) should be unobtrusive; critical actions (proposal rejected, date change denied, payment failed) must capture attention.

evidence.quote: Can you hear me, Susan? Me? Yep. Can you hear me? No, I, yeah. You're you're back. I can hear you. Can you hear me? Yes. I can hear you.
evidence.insight: A 20-second feedback gap on the phone call causes immediate anxiety and both parties scramble to re-establish communication. This is exactly what happens when a platform shows 'pending' for hours — the guest's trust erodes because the feedback channel appears broken.

evidence.quote: Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting. If the delay is too long, people often give up, going off to do other activities.
evidence.insight: Norman's 0.1-second threshold is about perceived responsiveness. For asynchronous actions like proposals, 'immediate' means instant acknowledgment of the action plus a realistic timeline for the outcome. The guest must never wonder whether their action registered.

evidence.quote: I'll be in contact with Rita. And like I said, I'll keep you updated.
evidence.insight: Bryant promises future feedback as the call ends. This human promise of ongoing communication is the only signifier Susan has for what happens next. The platform must replace this promise with systematic, reliable status notifications.

evidence.quote: Feedback has to be planned. All actions need to be confirmed, but in a manner that is unobtrusive. Feedback must also be prioritized, so that unimportant information is presented in an unobtrusive fashion, but important signals are presented in a way that does capture attention.
evidence.insight: The active lease generates many feedback moments (date confirmations, cleaning reminders, payment receipts). Each must be prioritized: critical signals (payment failed, host cancellation) must break through; routine signals (stay confirmed) should not become the 'backseat driver' Norman warns about.

elements.user_goal: Always know what is happening with my booking — whether my action was received, what the host decided, and what I should do next — without needing to check or call someone.
elements.company_goal: Reduce abandonment during asynchronous negotiation by replacing feedback gaps with proactive status communication that maintains guest engagement across the waiting period.
elements.time_budget: Action acknowledgment: under 1 second. Status update delivery: under 5 minutes for critical actions, under 1 hour for routine actions. Intermediate 'still waiting' feedback: every 6 hours for proposals, every 2 hours for time-sensitive requests.
anti_goals: DO NOT show a generic 'pending' state without a timeline. The guest must know when to expect a response.

DO NOT over-notify for routine events. Norman: 'Too much feedback can be even more annoying than too little.' Cleaning reminders and weekly stay confirmations should be quiet; payment failures and host cancellations should be loud.
DO NOT use identical notification patterns for different event types. If every notification looks the same, the guest will ignore all of them.
DO NOT replace human communication with automated messages that feel robotic. Status updates should feel informative and specific, not template-generated.
elements.success_metric: Guest engagement during negotiation: percentage of guests who remain active on the platform (checking status, responding to counter-offers) during the proposal-to-acceptance window. Target: above 60% still engaged after 24 hours. Secondary: average response time to host counter-offers under 4 hours.

elements.title: Support Proxy Booking as a First-Class Affordance
elements.problem: Susan is not the guest — she is booking on behalf of a friend from Oregon. She says 'I can give you a deposit on her behalf' (2:34), 'I'm setting up all appointments for her' (3:58-4:31), and 'before she puts her tickets' (2:14). The platform's conceptual model assumes the person searching, evaluating, proposing, and paying is the person who will stay. Norman's conceptual model principle states that 'a conceptual model is an explanation, usually highly simplified, of how something works. It doesn't have to be complete or even accurate as long as it is useful.' The one-guest-one-user model is not useful when proxies are involved. The platform affords booking (you can fill out forms and pay), but it does not signify proxy booking (there is no discoverable way to indicate 'I am booking for someone else'). The affordance may exist but without a signifier it is invisible. Susan would have to either pretend to be the guest or improvise a workaround — both of which create incorrect data and a broken conceptual model.
elements.solution: Make proxy booking a discoverable, signified affordance at every relevant phase. This requires: (1) During account creation or proposal creation, provide a clear signifier: 'Booking for yourself?' / 'Booking for someone else?' This single toggle changes the conceptual model from one-user to two-user and adjusts subsequent fields accordingly. (2) In the proposal, capture both the proxy's information (Susan: contact person, local presence, deposit payer) and the guest's information (friend: actual occupant, arrival date, Oregon address). (3) During the active lease, afford dual communication: both the proxy and the guest should receive status updates, feedback, and action prompts. Susan is coordinating locally; the friend is occupying remotely. Both need different information at different times. (4) The acceptance flow must clearly signify who is committing to what: the proxy commits the deposit, the guest commits to the stay. These are different actions by different people and must be signified as such. (5) Norman's constraint principle applies: the proxy's affordances should be constrained to coordination actions (pay deposit, communicate with host, manage schedule), while the guest's affordances include occupancy actions (check in, submit cleaning photos, write reviews).

evidence.quote: I like to see the place and I can give you a deposit on her behalf and she's ready to come whenever I can find her spot.
evidence.insight: Susan explicitly describes the proxy pattern: she inspects and pays, the friend occupies. The platform must afford this split-responsibility pattern, not force all actions through a single account.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: If the platform offers no signifier for proxy booking, a proxy user like Susan will not know it is possible, will not find the right path, and will either abandon or create a distorted booking under her own name.

evidence.quote: She's going to be out most of the day, you know, she has done appointments and all I'm setting up all appointments for her.
evidence.insight: Susan is managing her friend's schedule from a different location. During the active lease, the platform must support this distributed coordination pattern — one person managing logistics locally while another occupies the space.

evidence.quote: Good conceptual models are the key to understandable, enjoyable products: good communication is the key to good conceptual models.
evidence.insight: The platform's conceptual model must communicate a two-person booking structure clearly: who is the coordinator, who is the occupant, what can each person do. Without this, both users will struggle to understand their roles and available actions.

elements.user_goal: Book and manage a stay for someone else — paying the deposit, coordinating with the host, and receiving updates — without pretending to be the person who will actually stay there.
elements.company_goal: Capture a booking pattern that currently requires human mediation (Bryant coordinating between Susan and Rita) by making proxy booking self-service, expanding the addressable market to guests who are assisted by local contacts.
elements.time_budget: The proxy/self toggle should add no more than 10 seconds to the proposal flow. Subsequent dual-user fields should be pre-structured so both profiles can be completed in under 2 minutes total.
anti_goals: DO NOT force all actions through a single user account. The proxy and the guest are different people with different needs and different affordances.
DO NOT ignore the proxy after booking. Susan is the local contact, the deposit payer, and the schedule coordinator — she needs ongoing access and feedback, not just the initial payment form.

DO NOT require the guest to be present on the platform to complete the booking. If the friend is in Oregon with no account, Susan must be able to book on her behalf without the friend creating a profile first.
DO NOT treat proxy booking as an edge case hidden in settings. If it requires more than one click to discover, the signifier has failed for this user segment.
elements.success_metric: Proxy booking utilization rate: percentage of bookings where the paying user and the occupying user are different people, completed without agent assistance. Target: above 10% of all bookings. Secondary: proxy booking completion rate above 60% (vs. abandonment due to inability to express the proxy pattern).

elements.title: Bridge the Signifier-to-Reality Gap at Move-In with Knowledge-in-the-World
elements.problem: Susan's entire call is organized around preventing a catastrophic move-in failure. Her friend is flying from Oregon — the cost of a bad experience is not just the booking fee but an airline ticket, lost time, and a stranded person in an unfamiliar city. The listing page's signifiers (photos, description, price) make promises about the space. Move-in is the moment those promises are tested against reality. Norman distinguishes between 'knowledge in the head' (what the guest remembers from the listing) and 'knowledge in the world' (what is available in the environment at the moment of action). At move-in, the guest's knowledge in the head is limited and potentially distorted by the listing's signifiers. The guest needs knowledge in the world: how to enter the building, how to find the room, how to use the Wi-Fi, how to contact the host if something is wrong, and critically — how to exercise the cancellation guarantee if the space does not match the listing. None of this is discoverable from the space itself. The House Manual is the primary vehicle for delivering knowledge in the world, but only if it is accessible, complete, and organized around the guest's move-in sequence.
elements.solution: Design the move-in experience as a signifier-to-reality bridge that provides knowledge in the world at the exact moment the guest needs it. This requires: (1) A digital House Manual that is accessible from the guest's phone, organized chronologically by move-in sequence: access the building → find the room → check the space → connect to Wi-Fi → review the cancellation terms → contact the host. Not alphabetically. Not by topic. By the guest's actual action sequence. (2) The cancellation guarantee must be the most prominent signifier in the move-in flow, not buried in terms and conditions. Norman: 'Affordances exist even if they are not visible. For designers, their visibility is critical.' The guest must know they can leave on night one if the space does not match. (3) A move-in checklist that asks the guest to verify key claims from the listing: private bathroom? check. Private room? check. Wi-Fi works? check. This serves dual purpose: it gives the guest a structured way to verify (reducing anxiety) and it gives the platform data on listing accuracy. (4) Co-occupancy must be disclosed and discoverable before and during move-in. Susan asked 'Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?' (1:20). If the guest arrives to unexpected co-occupants, every prior signifier is invalidated. (5) A clear, signified feedback channel for move-in problems: a button or contact method that is visible on the first screen of the House Manual, not buried three levels deep.

evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's anxiety is specifically about the gap between listing claims and physical reality. The move-in experience must close this gap immediately — within the first 10 minutes of arrival — or the trust built through listing evaluation and negotiation collapses.

evidence.quote: Two of the most important characteristics of good design are discoverability and understanding. Discoverability: Is it possible to even figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them?
evidence.insight: At move-in, the guest must discover how to enter the building, access the room, use facilities, and contact the host — all without prior physical experience. Every one of these is an affordance that requires a signifier in the House Manual or check-in flow.

evidence.quote: Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?
evidence.insight: Co-occupancy is a critical move-in variable. If the guest discovers unexpected co-occupants at arrival, the listing's signifiers have failed catastrophically. This must be disclosed before move-in and verified at move-in.

evidence.quote: A good conceptual model allows us to predict the effects of our actions. Without a good model, we operate by rote, blindly; we do operations as we were told to do them; we can't fully appreciate why, what effects to expect, or what to do if things go wrong.
evidence.insight: At move-in, the guest needs a conceptual model of the space and its rules — not just the physical layout but the social contract: when to be quiet, how to handle shared spaces, what the host expects. The House Manual must provide this model, organized as knowledge-in-the-world that is available exactly when and where the guest needs it.

elements.user_goal: Arrive at the space and immediately know how to get in, verify it matches the listing, understand the rules, and know what to do if something is wrong — all from my phone, without calling anyone.
elements.company_goal: Prevent move-in failures that result in cancellations, negative reviews, and lost referral chains (Susan → friend → future word-of-mouth) by ensuring the physical experience matches the digital signifiers.
elements.time_budget: The guest should be able to access the building, enter the room, and confirm the space matches the listing within 15 minutes of arrival. The House Manual should be accessible in under 3 taps from the app home screen.
anti_goals: DO NOT organize the House Manual by topic (Wi-Fi, Appliances, Neighborhood). Organize it by the guest's action sequence at move-in.
DO NOT bury the cancellation guarantee in fine print. At move-in, it is the most important signifier — it is the safety net that made this entire booking possible.
DO NOT assume the guest will read the House Manual before arrival. It must be designed for just-in-time reference at the moment of need, not for advance study.
DO NOT rely solely on the host to communicate move-in details. The platform must have a structured, verified move-in flow that does not depend on the host remembering to send check-in instructions.
elements.success_metric: First-night cancellation rate: target below 5% (indicating that listing signifiers accurately predict reality). Secondary: move-in checklist completion rate above 70% (indicating guests are using the verification tool and finding it matches their needs).
